title: Method for producing difluorophosphate, non-aqueous electrolyte for secondary cell and non-aqueous electrolyte secondary cell

inventors.name: Ryoichi Mitsubishi Chem. Group Sci. & Tech. KATO
Hirofumi Mitsubishi Chem. Group Sci.&Tech. SUZUKI
Jun Mitsubishi Chem. Group Sci. & Tech. SASAHARA
Hitoshi Mitsubishi Chem. Group Sci.& Tech. SUZUKI

events.title: Application filed by Mitsubishi Chemical Corp

classifications.description: Rocking-chair batteries, i.e. batteries with lithium insertion or intercalation in both electrodes; Lithium-ion batteries
Liquid materials characterised by the additives
Liquid materials characterised by the solutes
Liquid materials characterised by the solvents
Manufacturing or production processes characterised by the final manufactured product

abstract: A difluorophosphate effective as an additive for a nonaqueous electrolyte for secondary battery is produced by a simple method from inexpensive common materials.  The difluorophosphate is produced by reacting lithium hexafluorophosphate with a carbonate in a nonaqueous solvent.  The liquid reaction mixture resulting from this reaction is supplied for providing the difluorophosphate in a nonaqueous electrolyte comprising a nonaqueous solvent which contains at least a hexafluorophosphate as an electrolyte lithium salt and further contains a difluorophosphate. Also provided is a nonaqueous-electrolyte secondary battery employing this nonaqueous electrolyte.
claims: A process for producing a difluorophosphate, which comprises reacting a lithium hexafluorophosphate with a carbonate in a nonaqueous solvent.

The process for producing a difluorophosphate as claimed in claim 1, wherein the carbonate is selected from the group consisting of alkali metal salts, alkaline earth metal salts, and salts represented by NR1R2R3R4, wherein R1 to R4 may be the same or different and each represents either an organic group having 1 to 12 carbon atoms or a hydrogen atom).

The process for producing a difluorophosphate as claimed in claim 1 or 2, wherein the nonaqueous solvent is one or more solvents selected from the group consisting of cyclic carbonates, linear carbonates, cyclic esters, linear esters, cyclic ethers, linear ethers, and sulfur-containing organic solvents.
The process for producing a difluorophosphate as claimed in any one of claims 1 to 3, wherein the nonaqueous solvent is a nonaqueous solvent having a relative permittivity of lower than 10.

A nonaqueous electrolyte for secondary battery, which comprises: a nonaqueous solvent containing at least a hexafluorophosphate as an electrolyte lithium salt; and further a difluorophosphate, wherein at least part of the difluorophosphate is one supplied as a liquid reaction mixture resulting from a reaction of lithium hexafluorophosphate with a carbonate in a nonaqueous solvent and containing a difluorophosphate.

The nonaqueous electrolyte for secondary battery as claimed in claim 5, wherein the carbonate is selected from the group consisting of alkali metal salts, alkaline earth metal salts, and salts represented by NR1R2R3R4, wherein R1 to R4 may be the same or different and each represents either an organic group having 1-12 carbon atoms or a hydrogen atom).

The nonaqueous electrolyte for secondary battery as claimed in claim 5 or 6, wherein the nonaqueous solvent is selected from the group consisting of ethylene carbonate, propylene carbonate, dimethyl carbonate, diethyl carbonate, and ethyl methyl carbonate.

The nonaqueous electrolyte for secondary battery as claimed in claim 5 or 6, wherein the liquid reaction mixture is one obtained by conducting the reaction of lithium hexafluorophosphate with carbonate in a nonaqueous solvent having a relative permittivity of lower than 10 and thereafter mixing the resultant reaction mixture with a nonaqueous solvent having a relative permittivity of 10 or higher.

The nonaqueous electrolyte for secondary battery as claimed in claim 8, wherein the nonaqueous solvent having a relative permittivity of lower than 10 is one or more solvents selected from the group consisting of linear carbonates, linear esters, cyclic ethers, and linear ethers.

The nonaqueous electrolyte for secondary battery as claimed in claim 8, wherein the nonaqueous solvent having a relative permittivity of 10 or higher is one or more solvents selected from the group consisting of cyclic carbonates or cyclic esters.

The nonaqueous electrolyte for secondary battery as claimed in claim 9, wherein the linear carbonates are selected from the group consisting of dimethyl carbonate, diethyl carbonate, and ethyl methyl carbonate.

The nonaqueous electrolyte for secondary battery as claimed in claim 10, wherein the cyclic carbonates or cyclic esters are selected from the group consisting of ethylene carbonate, propylene carbonate, γ-butyrolactone, and γ-valerolactone.

The nonaqueous electrolyte for secondary battery as claimed in claim 8, wherein the nonaqueous solvent having a relative permittivity of lower than 10 is a mixed solvent comprising dimethyl carbonate and ethyl methyl carbonate and the nonaqueous solvent having a relative permittivity of 10 or higher is ethylene carbonate.

The nonaqueous electrolyte for secondary battery as claimed in any one of claims 5 to 13, wherein the concentration of the difluorophosphate in the nonaqueous electrolyte is 1×10-2 mol/kg or more and 0.5 mol/kg or less.

A nonaqueous electrolyte for secondary battery, which comprises: a nonaqueous solvent containing at least a hexafluorophosphate as an electrolyte lithium salt; a difluorophosphate; and a fluoride salt.

A nonaqueous electrolyte for secondary battery, which comprises: a nonaqueous solvent containing at least a hexafluorophosphate as an electrolyte lithium salt; further a difluorophosphate; and carbon dioxide.

A nonaqueous electrolyte for secondary battery, which comprises; a nonaqueous solvent containing at least a hexafluorophosphate as an electrolyte lithium salt; and further a lithium difluorophosphate, wherein the nonaqueous solvent is a mixed solvent composed of three or more nonaqueous solvent ingredients comprising both of cyclic carbonate and linear carbonate.

The nonaqueous electrolyte for secondary battery as claimed in claim 15, wherein the nonaqueous solvent comprises one or more members selected from the group consisting of ethylene carbonate, propylene carbonate, dimethyl carbonate, diethyl carbonate, and ethyl methyl carbonate.

The nonaqueous electrolyte for secondary battery as claimed in claim 15, wherein the nonaqueous solvent is a mixed solvent at least comprising ethylene carbonate (EC), dimethyl carbonate (DMC), and diethyl carbonate (DEC).

The nonaqueous electrolyte for secondary battery as claimed in claim 15, wherein the nonaqueous solvent is a mixed solvent at least comprising ethylene carbonate (EC), dimethyl carbonate (DMC), and ethyl methyl carbonate (EMC).

The nonaqueous electrolyte for secondary battery as claimed in any one of claims 5 to 20, wherein the concentration of the difluorophosphate in the nonaqueous electrolyte is 1×10-2 mol/kg or more and 0.5 mol/kg or less.

A nonaqueous-electrolyte secondary battery comprising: a nonaqueous electrolyte; a negative electrode capable of occluding and releasing lithium ions; and a positive electrode, wherein the nonaqueous electrolyte is the nonaqueous electrolyte for secondary battery as claimed in any one of claims 5 to 21.

A nonaqueous-electrolyte secondary battery comprising: a nonaqueous electrolyte; a negative electrode capable of occluding and releasing lithium ions; and a positive electrode, wherein the nonaqueous electrolyte is the nonaqueous electrolyte for secondary battery as claimed in any one of claims 5 to 21, and the secondary battery satisfies at least one requirement selected from the group consisting of the following (i), (ii), and (iii):
(i) an overall electrode area of the positive electrode is 20 times or more the surface area of case of the secondary battery;
(ii) the secondary battery has a direct-current resistance component of less than 10 milliohms (mΩ); and
(iii) the battery elements disposed in each battery case of the secondary battery have an electric capacity of 3 ampere-hours (Ah) or higher.
